cards.name: Amulet of Kroog
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn.
cards.flavor: Among the first allies Urza gained were the people of Kroog. As a sign of friendship, Urza gave the healers of the city potent amulets; afterwards, thousands journeyed to Kroog in hope of healing, greatly adding to the city's glory.

cards.name: Argivian Archaeologist
cards.text: {W}{W}, {T}: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: Fascinated by the lore of ancient struggles, the Archaeologist searches incessantly for remnants of an earlier, more powerful era.

cards.name: Argivian Blacksmith
cards.text: {T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to target artifact creature this turn.
cards.flavor: Through years of study and training, the Blacksmiths of Argive became adept at reassembling the mangled remains of the strange, mechanical creatures abounding in their native land.

cards.name: Argothian Pixies
cards.text:
Argothian Pixies can't be blocked by artifact creatures.

Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Argothian Pixies by artifact creatures.
cards.flavor: After the rape of Argoth Forest during the rule of the artificers, the Pixies of Argoth bent their magic to more practical ends.

cards.name: Argothian Treefolk
cards.text: Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Argothian Treefolk by artifact sources.
cards.flavor:
Haunting cries we hear in our dreams

As the forest dies, a death from

machines.

cards.name: Armageddon Clock
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a doom counter on Armageddon Clock.

At the beginning of your draw step, Armageddon Clock deals damage equal to the number of doom counters on it to each player.

{4}: Remove a doom counter from Armageddon Clock. Any player may activate this ability but only during any upkeep step.

rulings.text: Players can remove as many counters as they can pay for each turn.

cards.name: Artifact Blast
cards.text: Counter target artifact spell.
cards.flavor: The first line of defense against Urza and Mishra, the Artifact Blast achieved widespread fame until an unlucky mage discovered it was useless on the devices the brothers had already created.

cards.name: Artifact Possession
cards.text:
Enchant artifact

Whenever enchanted artifact becomes tapped or a player activates an ability of enchanted artifact without {T} in its activation cost, Artifact Possession deals 2 damage to that artifact's controller.
cards.flavor: Any black mage could coax a Thraxodemon to inhabit a magical device.

cards.name: Artifact Ward
cards.text:
Enchant creature

Enchanted creature can't be blocked by artifact creatures. 

Prevent all damage that would be dealt to enchanted creature by artifact sources.

Enchanted creature can't be the target of abilities from artifact sources.

cards.name: Ashnod's Altar
cards.text: Sacrifice a creature: Add {2} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Ashnod's Battle Gear
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Ashnod's Battle Gear during your untap step.

{2}, {T}: Target creature you control gets +2/-2 for as long as Ashnod's Battle Gear remains tapped.
cards.flavor: This horrid invention clearly illustrates why Mishra's lieutenant was feared as much by her troops as by her foes.

cards.name: Ashnod's Transmogrant
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Ashnod's Transmogrant: Put a +1/+1 counter on target nonartifact creature. That creature becomes an artifact in addition to its other types.
cards.flavor: Ashnod found few willing to trade their humanity for the power she offered them.

cards.name: Atog
cards.text: Sacrifice an artifact: Atog gets +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Battering Ram
cards.text:
At the beginning of combat on your turn, Battering Ram gains banding until end of combat. (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's blocking.)

Whenever Battering Ram becomes blocked by a Wall, destroy that Wall at end of combat.
cards.flavor: By the time Mishra was defeated, no mage was foolish enough to rely heavily on walls.

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.name: Bronze Tablet
cards.text:
Remove Bronze Tablet from your deck before playing if you're not playing for ante.

Bronze Tablet enters the battlefield tapped.

{4}, {T}: Exile Bronze Tablet and target nontoken permanent an opponent owns. That player may pay 10 life. If he or she does, put Bronze Tablet into its owner's graveyard. Otherwise, that player owns Bronze Tablet and you own the other exiled card.

rulings.text: If using a copy of the Tablet, you must trade the copy card to your opponent just like you would have traded the Tablet.
You can't choose to pay 10 life if you have less than 10 life, but you may choose to give up the game immediately. This has roughly the same effect.
You can take control of your opponent's Tablet and in the trade you only have to give them back their Tablet.
If the card being targeted by the Bronze Tablet is removed before Tablet takes effect, then the Tablet ability is countered and it remains tapped.

If the tablet is not still on the battlefield when the ability resolves, it is not exiled. The other player still has the choice to pay 10 life, and you still become the owner of their card if they choose not to do so.

cards.name: Candelabra of Tawnos
cards.text: {X}, {T}: Untap X target lands.
cards.flavor: Tawnos learned quickly from Urza that utter simplicity often led to wondrous, yet subtle utility.

rulings.text: You may untap your opponent's lands if desired.
Can be used on an untapped land.
This is not mana ability. It is a normal ability and it will resolve along with other spells and abilities on the stack. The lands untap during resolution.

cards.name: Circle of Protection: Artifacts
cards.text: {2}: The next time an artifact source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.

cards.name: Citanul Druid
cards.text: Whenever an opponent casts an artifact spell, put a +1/+1 counter on Citanul Druid.
cards.flavor: Driven mad by the fall of Argoth, the Citanul Druids found peace only in battle.

rulings.text: In multiplayer games it affects all players.

cards.name: Clay Statue
cards.text: {2}: Regenerate Clay Statue.
cards.flavor: Tawnos won fame as Urza's greatest assistant. After he created these warriors, Urza ended his apprenticeship, promoting him directly to the rank of master.

cards.name: Clockwork Avian
cards.text:
Flying

Clockwork Avian enters the battlefield with four +1/+0 counters on it.

At end of combat, if Clockwork Avian attacked or blocked this combat, remove a +1/+0 counter from it.

{X}, {T}: Put up to X +1/+0 counters on Clockwork Avian. This ability can't cause the total number of +1/+0 counters on Clockwork Avian to be greater than four. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.

rulings.text: Loses a counter even if it is affected by a Fog-like effect which prevents it from dealing damage.
Can attack or block even if it has no counters.
If the ability to add counters resolves when there are already the maximum number of counters on it, any counters over the maximum are simply not added.

cards.name: Colossus of Sardia
cards.text:
Trample (If this creature would assign enough damage to its blockers to destroy them, you may have it assign the rest of its damage to defending player or planeswalker.)

Colossus of Sardia doesn't untap during your untap step.

{9}: Untap Colossus of Sardia. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.
cards.flavor:
From the Sardian mountains wakes ancient doom:

Warrior born from a rocky womb.

rulings.text: The ability that untaps it during your upkeep has been returned to an activated ability. There is no restriction on how many times it can be untapped during your upkeep with this ability.

cards.name: Coral Helm
cards.text: {3}, Discard a card at random: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Crumble
cards.text: Destroy target artifact. It can't be regenerated. That artifact's controller gains life equal to its converted mana cost.
cards.flavor: The spirits of Argoth grant new life to those who repent the folly of enslaving their labors to devices.

rulings.text: If the target artifact becomes illegal before resolution, the player does not gain any life.

cards.name: Cursed Rack
cards.text:
As Cursed Rack enters the battlefield, choose an opponent.

The chosen player's maximum hand size is four.
cards.flavor: Ashnod invented several torture techniques that could make victims even miles away beg for mercy as if the End had come.

rulings.text: The effect of lowering the maximum hand size makes it so the player discards down to 4 cards (instead of the usual 7) during the cleanup step.

You choose one opposing player just as this card is entering the battlefield and it only affects that one player. This choice is not changed even if this card changes controllers. It becomes useless but stays on the battlefield if the chosen player leaves the game.

If multiple effects modify your hand size, apply them in timestamp order. For example, if you put Null Profusion (an enchantment that says your maximum hand size is two) onto the battlefield and then a player puts Cursed Rack onto the battlefield choosing you, your maximum hand size will be four. However, if those permanents entered the battlefield in the opposite order, your maximum hand size would be two.

cards.name: Damping Field
cards.text: Players can't untap more than one artifact during their untap steps.
cards.flavor: Eventually, mages learned to harness the power of natural damping fields and use it for their own ends.

rulings.text: Artifact creatures are artifacts. They are affected so only one may untap.
Damping Field does not prevent artifacts being untapped by spells or abilities at other times.

cards.name: Detonate
cards.text: Destroy target artifact with converted mana cost X. It can't be regenerated. Detonate deals X damage to that artifact's controller.

rulings.text: If the artifact becomes an illegal target before resolution, then no damage is done.

cards.name: Drafna's Restoration
cards.text: Return any number of target artifact cards from target player's graveyard to the top of his or her library in any order.
cards.flavor: Drafna, founder of the College of Lat-Nam, could create a working model from even the smallest remnants of a newly unearthed artifact.

cards.name: Dragon Engine
cards.text: {2}: Dragon Engine gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Those who believed the city of Kroog would never fall to Mishra's forces severely underestimated the might of his war machines.

cards.name: Dwarven Weaponsmith
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.

cards.name: Energy Flux
cards.text: All artifacts have "At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice this artifact unless you pay {2}."

cards.name: Feldon's Cane
cards.text: {T}, Exile Feldon's Cane: Shuffle your graveyard into your library.
cards.flavor: Feldon found the first of these canes frozen in the Ronom Glacier

cards.name: Gaea's Avenger
cards.text: Gaea's Avenger's power and toughness are each equal to 1 plus the number of artifacts your opponents control.
cards.flavor: After the destruction of Argoth, Gaea was willing to instill a portion of her own powers into some of her more vengeful followers.

rulings.text: In multi-player games it counts artifacts of all opponents.

cards.name: Gate to Phyrexia
cards.text: Sacrifice a creature: Destroy target artifact. Activate this ability only during your upkeep and only once each turn.
cards.flavor: "The warm rain of grease on my face immediately made it clear I had entered Phyrexia."Jarsyl, Diary

cards.name: Goblin Artisans
cards.text: {T}: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, draw a card. If you lose the flip, counter target artifact spell you control that isn't the target of an ability from another creature named Goblin Artisans.

cards.name: Golgothian Sylex
cards.text: {1}, {T}: Each nontoken permanent from the Antiquities expansion is sacrificed by its controller.
cards.flavor: From their earliest educations, the brothers had known that no human contrivance could stand against the true masters of Dominia.

cards.name: Grapeshot Catapult
cards.text: {T}: Grapeshot Catapult deals 1 damage to target creature with flying.
cards.flavor: For years scholars debated whether these were Urza's or Mishra's creations. Recent research suggests they were invented by the brothers' original master, Tocasia, and that both used these devices.

cards.name: Haunting Wind
cards.text: Whenever an artifact becomes tapped or a player activates an artifact's ability without {T} in its activation cost, Haunting Wind deals 1 damage to that artifact's controller.
cards.flavor: These devices lured so many spirits that sometimes entire battlefields would become haunted at once.

cards.name: Hurkyl's Recall
cards.text: Return all artifacts target player owns to his or her hand.
cards.flavor: This spell, attributed to Drafna, was actually the work of his wife Hurkyl.

rulings.text: Retrieves all artifacts owned by the target player regardless of who controls them. Ignores artifacts owned by other players even if target player has control of them.
It only returns artifacts which are on the battlefield.

cards.name: Ivory Tower
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you gain X life, where X is the number of cards in your hand minus 4.
cards.flavor: Valuing scholarship above all else, the inhabitants of the Ivory Tower reward those who sacrifice power for knowledge.

rulings.text: If you have four or fewer cards in your hand when Ivory Tower's ability resolves, the ability has no effect.

cards.name: Jalum Tome
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: This timeworn relic was responsible for many of Urza's victories, though he never fully comprehended its mystical runes.

cards.name: Martyrs of Korlis
cards.text: As long as Martyrs of Korlis is untapped, all damage that would be dealt to you by artifacts is dealt to Martyrs of Korlis instead.

rulings.text: If you have multiple Martyrs of Korlis, you can decide which one receives the redirected damage each time artifact damage would be dealt to you.

cards.name: Mightstone
cards.text: Attacking creatures get +1/+0.
cards.flavor: While exploring the sacred cave of Koilos with his brother Mishra and their master Tocasia, Urza fell behind in the Hall of Tagsin, where he discovered the remarkable Mightstone.

rulings.text: The +1/+0 applies to attacking creatures from all players.

cards.name: Millstone
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Target player puts the top two cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
cards.flavor: More than one mage was driven insane by the sound of the Millstone relentlessly grinding away.

rulings.text: Can be used on a player with less than 2 cards in their library. It will remove 0 or 1 cards if that is all that is available.
It is not a draw effect so it will not cause a player with less than 2 cards in their library to lose.
Since you are putting more than one card in the graveyard at one time, the affected player can choose the order the 2 cards go in.

cards.name: Mishra's Factory
cards.text:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.

{1}: Mishra's Factory becomes a 2/2 Assembly-Worker artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.

{T}: Target Assembly-Worker creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: When it is an Assembly-Worker, it is an artifact and can therefore be affected by spells and abilities that affect artifacts.
When it is an Assembly-Worker, it is still a land and retains all of its other abilities.
Any counters on the Assembly-Worker remain even if the counters stop being meaningful when it de-animates.

If an Assembly-Worker is changed to another land type, it will stay a 2/2 artifact creature and keep the creature type "Assembly-Worker" (until end of turn), but it will change its land type as directed.
Tapping a land for something other than mana is not a mana ability.
When animated into an Assembly-Worker, it has creature type Assembly-Worker.
The card name does not change. It remains "Mishra's Factory".

If another player takes control of the Factory while it is animated, that player keeps control until the control effect ends. They do not lose control just because the card stops being an Assembly-Worker. Note that Auras which steal cards will go to the graveyard if the permanent they enchant is no longer valid.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of his or her most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it's already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

cards.name: Mishra's War Machine
cards.text:
Banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)

At the beginning of your upkeep, Mishra's War Machine deals 3 damage to you unless you discard a card. If Mishra's War Machine deals damage to you this way, tap it.

rulings.text: You may choose to take damage or to discard. You can't avoid taking damage if you have no cards to discard.

cards.name: Mishra's Workshop
cards.text: {T}: Add {3} to your mana pool. Spend this mana only to cast artifact spells.
cards.flavor: Though he eventually came to despise Tocasia, Mishra listened well to her lessons on clarity of purpose. Unlike his brother, he focused his mind on a single goal.

rulings.text: You can spend the mana on costs on the spell's text.
The mana can't be used to pay Echo costs.
This mana may not be used to pay costs imposed after the spell is initially cast.
This mana may be used on additional costs to cast the spell, such as Kicker.

cards.name: Obelisk of Undoing
cards.text: {6}, {T}: Return target permanent you both own and control to your hand.
cards.flavor: The Battle of Tomakul taught Urza not to rely on fickle reinforcements.

cards.name: Onulet
cards.text: When Onulet dies, you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: An early inspiration for Urza, Tocasia's Onulets contained magical essences that could be cannibalized after they stopped functioning.

cards.name: Orcish Mechanics
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Orcish Mechanics deals 2 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Ornithopter
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor: Many scholars believe that these creatures were the result of Urza's first attempt at mechanical life, perhaps created in his early days as an apprentice to Tocasia.

cards.name: Phyrexian Gremlins
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Phyrexian Gremlins during your untap step.

{T}: Tap target artifact. It doesn't untap during its controller's untap step for as long as Phyrexian Gremlins remains tapped.

rulings.text: If the Gremlins somehow become an artifact and then tap themselves, they can never be untapped during the untap phase. They must be untapped by an external effect.
Only prevents the artifact from untapping during untap step. Ones that untap during upkeep are not inhibited.
The target artifact can't untap if the Gremlins and the artifact are tapped during untap, even if it is your artifact, and you plan on untapping the Gremlins.
The effect does not end if the target stops being valid. For example, if it stops being an artifact.
Can target a tapped artifact.

cards.name: Power Artifact
cards.text:
Enchant artifact

Enchanted artifact's activated abilities cost {2} less to activate. This effect can't reduce the amount of mana an ability costs to activate to less than one mana.

rulings.text: Only affects the generic mana part of activation costs. Colored parts of mana costs are not affected.
Can be placed on artifacts with no or zero activation costs, but this has no effect on them. It does not increase the cost to one.
Can’t reduce Snow mana costs.

cards.name: Powerleech
cards.text: Whenever an artifact an opponent controls becomes tapped or an opponent activates an artifact's ability without {T} in its activation cost, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: The Forest of Argoth has developed a resistance to mechanical intrusion.

rulings.text: In a multi-player game it affects all opponents.

cards.name: Priest of Yawgmoth
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Add to your mana pool an amount of {B} equal to the sacrificed artifact's converted mana cost.

cards.name: Primal Clay
cards.text: As Primal Clay enters the battlefield, it becomes your choice of a 3/3 artifact creature, a 2/2 artifact creature with flying, or a 1/6 Wall artifact creature with defender in addition to its other types. (A creature with defender can't attack.)

rulings.text: In zones other than the battlefield, Primal Clay is 0/0.

If another permanent enters the battlefield as a copy of Primal Clay, the controller of that permanent will get to make a new choice. The copy won't necessarily have the same power, toughness, and abilities as the original.
If a creature that's already on the battlefield becomes a copy of Primal Clay, it copies the power, toughness, and abilities that were chosen for Primal Clay when it entered the battlefield.

cards.name: Rakalite
cards.text: {2}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn. Return Rakalite to its owner's hand at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor: Urza was the first to understand that the war would not be lost for lack of power, but for lack of troops.

rulings.text: Only returns to your hand if it is still on the battlefield at the end of the turn. If it leaves the battlefield, it does not return.
Can be used any number of times during the turn before it leaves the battlefield.
Can choose a different creature or player for each use.

cards.name: Reconstruction
cards.text: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: Tedious research made the Sages of the College of Lat-Nam adept in repairing broken artifacts.

cards.name: Reverse Polarity
cards.text: You gain X life, where X is twice the damage dealt to you so far this turn by artifacts.

cards.name: Rocket Launcher
cards.text: {2}: Rocket Launcher deals 1 damage to target creature or player. Destroy Rocket Launcher at the beginning of the next end step. Activate this ability only if you've controlled Rocket Launcher continuously since the beginning of your most recent turn.
cards.flavor: What these devices lacked in subtlety, they made up in strength.

rulings.text: You can choose different targets for each use.
Because it does not have tapping as part of its activation cost, you can activate the ability many times in one turn, but it is destroyed at the end of any turn in which you use it.
It is only destroyed at end of turn if the ability resolved. If the ability is countered, it is not sacrificed.

cards.name: Sage of Lat-Nam
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice an artifact: Draw a card.

cards.name: Shapeshifter
cards.text:
As Shapeshifter enters the battlefield, choose a number between 0 and 7.

At the beginning of your upkeep, you may choose a number between 0 and 7.

Shapeshifter's power is equal to the last chosen number and its toughness is equal to 7 minus that number.
cards.flavor:
Born like a Phoenix from the Flame,

But neither Bulk nor Shape the same.

—Jonathan Swift, "Vanbrug's House"

rulings.text: The ability that sets its power and toughness is a characteristic-defining ability. This means it applies before any other effects that modify power and/or toughness.

cards.name: Tawnos's Coffin
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Tawnos's Coffin during your untap step.

{3}, {T}: Exile target creature and all Auras attached to it. Note the number and kind of counters that were on that creature. When Tawnos's Coffin leaves the battlefield or becomes untapped, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control tapped with the noted number and kind of counters on it, and if you do, return the exiled Aura cards to the battlefield under their owner's control attached to that permanent.

rulings.text: The creature returns to the battlefield tapped. It does not return to the battlefield and then tap afterwards.
Because the new wording doesn't use phasing, the exiled card will suffer from summoning sickness upon its return to the battlefield.
The effect doesn't care what types the card has after it is exiled, only that it have been a creature while on the battlefield.

cards.name: Tetravus
cards.text:
Flying

Tetravus enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it. 

At the beginning of your upkeep, you may remove any number of +1/+1 counters from Tetravus. If you do, put that many 1/1 colorless Tetravite artifact creature tokens onto the battlefield. They each have flying and "This creature can't be enchanted."

At the beginning of your upkeep, you may exile any number of tokens put onto the battlefield with Tetravus. If you do, put that many +1/+1 counters on Tetravus.

rulings.text: If the Tetravus is destroyed when the Tetravites are off the card, they are not destroyed, they are just orphaned.
Any +1/+1 counter which is on this card can be turned into a Tetravite token. It does not care where the +1/+1 counter came from.
Only Tetravites from this specific Tetravus may be used for the ability. Ones from a different Tetravus can't.
This card now has two upkeep-triggered abilities. Its controller chooses the order they are put on the stack, and thus the order in which they resolve each upkeep.

cards.name: The Rack
cards.text:
As The Rack enters the battlefield, choose an opponent.

At the beginning of the chosen player's upkeep, The Rack deals X damage to that player, where X is 3 minus the number of cards in his or her hand.
cards.flavor: Invented in Mishra's earlier days, the Rack was once his most feared creation.

rulings.text: You choose one opposing player as this card enters the battlefield and it only affects that one player. This choice is not changed even if this card changes controllers. It becomes useless but stays on the battlefield if the chosen player leaves the battlefield.

cards.name: Titania's Song
cards.text: Each noncreature artifact loses all abilities and becomes an artifact creature with power and toughness each equal to its converted mana cost. If Titania's Song leaves the battlefield, this effect continues until end of turn.

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of his or her most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

cards.name: Transmute Artifact
cards.text: Sacrifice an artifact. If you do, search your library for an artifact card. If that card's converted mana cost is less than or equal to the sacrificed artifact's converted mana cost, put it onto the battlefield. If it's greater, you may pay {X}, where X is the difference. If you do, put it onto the battlefield. If you don't, put it into its owner's graveyard. Then shuffle your library.

rulings.text: Additional mana spent to cover the differences in mana costs is not part of the mana cost of this spell. It is spent during spell resolution.
The one from the library enters the battlefield when the spell is resolved, and this does not count as the casting of an artifact.
You can't sacrifice more than one artifact to this spell.
If the chosen artifact costs less than or the same as the sacrificed artifact, you simply put it onto the battlefield without paying any additional costs.
Because the "search" requires you to find a card with certain characteristics, you don't have to find the card if you don't want to.
The sacrifice of an artifact is an effect of the spell, not a cost, which means it happens as the spell resolves. If Transmute Artifact is countered, you do not have to sacrifice an artifact.

cards.name: Triskelion
cards.text:
Triskelion enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.

Remove a +1/+1 counter from Triskelion: Triskelion deals 1 damage to target creature or player.
cards.flavor: A brainchild of Tawnos, the Triskelion proved its versatility ans usefulness in many of the later battles between the brothers.

rulings.text: If you activate the ability of an attacking or blocking Triskelion during the declare blockers step, it will deal less combat damage as a result. If you wait until the combat damage step, but Triskelion is dealt lethal damage, it'll be destroyed before you get a chance to activate its ability.

If Triskelion has damage marked on it, activating its ability may cause that damage to become lethal. For example, say a Triskelion with two +1/+1 counters on it has been dealt 2 damage earlier in the turn. If you activate its ability by removing a +1/+1 counter from it, it now has 2 toughness and is destroyed as a state-based action. You won't be able to remove the other +1/+1 counter from it to activate its ability again. The first activation of the ability will still resolve.
